properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Sunday into Sunday night. Snow is expected to begin Sunday afternoon. 5 to 10 cm of snow is possible before the snow tapers off Monday morning. Travel is expected to be impacted due to moderate to heavy snow. Motorists should be prepared for winter weather driving conditions. This is a result of a Colorado Low that will track from Ohio towards the St. Lawrence River Sunday into Monday. There is still some uncertainty in model guidance as to the exact track of the low and the axis of heaviest snow. We will continue to monitor the situation and update Special Weather Statements as newer data becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-22T12:33:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-21T20:34:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1463647667.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Locations: Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm, with highest amounts in the west and south. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h. Stronger coastal gusts possible. Time span: Monday night through Tuesday night. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds and rain will spread from west to east across the Island Monday night into Tuesday. The heaviest rainfall rates and amounts are expected over western and southern Newfoundland on Tuesday, and into Tuesday evening in the east. The rain will taper to flurries as strong northwesterly winds cause cooler temperatures to spread across the Island Tuesday night. Rainfall and wind warnings will likely be issued with subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-22T11:21:52-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, rain, and wind expected beginning Monday night. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm, with higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h or higher. Locations: central and coastal Labrador. Time span: Monday night through Tuesday night. Remarks: Snow will develop over central Labrador late in the day on Monday and spread to coastal areas Monday night. Strong northwesterly winds and falling temperatures will combine with the snow causing a possibility of blowing snow over central and coastal Labrador Tuesday into Tuesday night, before the snow tapers off and winds ease. Over southeastern Labrador, a transition to rain is expected to occur early Tuesday. Significant rainfall amounts are possible along the Labrador Straits on Tuesday, before the rain changes back to snow late in the day. Warnings and watches will likely be issued with subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-22T11:58:04-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Sunday into Sunday night. Snow is expected to begin Sunday morning. 5 to 10 cm of snow is possible before the snow tapers off overnight. An exception will be areas near Lake Ontario where snow will be very wet. This should preclude significant accumulations in areas near the lake. Travel is expected to be impacted due to moderate to heavy snow. Motorists should be prepared for winter weather driving conditions. This is a result of a Colorado Low that will track from Ohio towards the St. Lawrence River Sunday into Monday. There is still some uncertainty in model guidance as to the exact track of the low and the axis of heaviest snow. We will continue to monitor the situation and update Special Weather Statements as newer data becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system approaching the North Coast is bringing heavy snow near Stewart this morning. The heavy snow will continue this afternoon and evening then end overnight. Snowfall accumulations of 20 to 25 cm are expected by Sunday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A Pacific disturbance moving into central Yukon today will create strong east winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 near the Richardson Mountains by this afternoon. These strong winds will give poor visibility in blowing snow and wind chill values near minus 30. Blizzard conditions will persist through tonight and then end early Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-22T03:20:56-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall Sunday evening. Snow is expected over Southern and Central Quebec Sunday night. Snowfall amounts could exceed 15 centimetres for regions north of the St-Lawrence River. Regions near the St-Lawrence River are expected to receive 5 to 10 centimetres before the snow changes to rain late in the night. There is a risk of freezing rain for the north shore of Montreal and the Laurentians during the changeover. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions are forecast to develop in Clyde River tonight. A low pressure system over Davis Strait will intensify through the evening hours. Snow will become heavier in Clyde River overnight and northwest winds will increase to 60 gusting 80 km/h. Blizzard conditions will persist through Sunday before improving Monday morning as snow tapers off and winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-22T12:19:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-21T20:20:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1982977858.2020
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Stagnant winter weather conditions are creating elevated pollution levels. Higher pollution levels are expected to persist through Monday. The Ministry of Environment and ClimateChange Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Valemount due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Restrictions on open burning are now in effect for all areas within Robson Valley Timber Supply Area until November 23, 2020 at 9:00 AM local time. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca Mandatory Emission Reduction Actions: As pollution is occurring or is likely to occur from open burning, pursuant to Section 30 (1) and (2) of the Open Burning Smoke Control Regulation, the Director has prohibited open burning in the Robson Valley Timber Supply Area until November 23, 2020 at 9:00 AM local time. No vegetative debris may be ignited or added to ignited piles. Contravention of these provisions may be subject to a fine under the Regulation. Voluntary Emission Reduction Actions: Where woodstoves or fireplaces are the sole source of residential heat, burn dry woodand ensure an adequate supply of combustion air. Reduce the use and idling of vehicles. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-11-22T04:29:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-11-21T12:30:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1552120460.2020
Area: Yellowhead
